contextId.information: Peter speaks of his readers as people who live away from their homes in many different countries. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the foreigners of the dispersion

contextId.information: Peter uses three similar phrases to describe the inheritance as something that is perfect and eternal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will not perish, will not become stained, and will not fade away

contextId.information: In the same way in which fire refines gold, hardships test how well believers trust in Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: This is for the proving of your faith

contextId.information: Peter speaks of his readers as if they were people living in a foreign land away from their home. AT: "spend the time you are living away from your true home" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: spend the time of your journey

contextId.information: Here Peter speaks of the believers as if they had made themselves pure. In reality, they have done nothing but accept salvation from Christ. [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You made your souls pure

contextId.information: Here the idea of cleanliness refers to being acceptable to God. [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: pure

contextId.information: These sinful actions are spoken of as if they were objects that people could throw away. The word "Therefore" here refers back to everything that Peter has said about being holy and obedient. AT: "So then, get rid of" or "So then, stop" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Therefore put aside all evil, all deceit, hypocrisy, envy, and all slander

contextId.information: Peter speaks of his readers as if they were babies. Babies requires very pure food, which they can digest easily. In the same way, believers need pure teaching from God's word. AT: "Just as babies long for their mother's breast milk, so you must yearn for pure spiritual milk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: As newborn infants, long for pure spiritual milk

contextId.information: Peter speaks of the word of God as if it were spiritual milk that nourished children. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: pure spiritual milk

contextId.information: Here to taste means to experience something personally. AT: "if you have experienced the Lord's kindness toward you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: if you have tasted that the Lord is kind

contextId.information: Peter speaks of Jesus as if he were a stone in a building. AT: "Come to him who is like a stone in a building, but alive, not a dead stone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Come to him who is a living stone

contextId.information: Just as people used stones to build the temple in the Old Testament, believers are the materials that God is using to build a house in which he will live. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You also are ... being built up to be a spiritual house

contextId.information: The scriptures are spoken of as if they were a container. This passage refers to the words that a person reads in scripture. AT: "This is what a prophet wrote in the scriptures long ago" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Scripture contains this

contextId.information: Here "darkness" refers to their condition as sinful people who did not know God, and "light" refers to their condition as people who do know God and practice righteousness. AT: "from a life of sin and ignorance of God to a life of knowing and pleasing him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: from darkness into his marvelous light

contextId.information: Peter speaks of their condition as free people as something that they use to hide sinful behavior. AT: "as an excuse to do wicked things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: as a covering for wickedness

contextId.information: Peter speaks of God's opinion of a person as if that person were standing directly in front of him. AT: "which God considers to be precious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: which is precious before God

contextId.information: Peter says that believing women who act as Sarah acted can be thought of as if they were her actual children. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You are now her children

contextId.information: Peter speaks of women as if they were containers, as men are sometimes also spoken as. AT: "wives, understanding that the woman is the weaker partner" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: wives according to understanding, as with a weaker container, a woman

contextId.information: Eternal life is often spoken of as if it were something that people inherited.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: heirs of the gift of life

contextId.information: Peter speaks of responding to the actions of another person as remitting payment for those actions. AT: "Do not do evil to someone who does evil to you or insult someone who insults you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not pay back evil for evil or insult for insult

contextId.information: Peter speaks of receiving God's blessing as receiving an inheritance. AT: "that you might receive God's blessing as your permanent possession" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that you might inherit a blessing

contextId.information: The phrase "set apart the Lord Christ ... as holy" means to acknowledge Christ's holiness. This action is referred to as if it were putting something in a place of honor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: set apart the Lord Christ in your hearts as holy

contextId.information: Peter probably means here that Christ died in order to create a close relationship between us and God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that he would bring us to God

contextId.information: Here "flesh" refers to Christ's body; Christ was physically put to death. This can be stated in active form. AT: "People put Christ to death physically" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: He was put to death in the flesh

contextId.information: The phrase "arm yourselves" makes readers think of soldiers who get their weapons ready for battle. It also pictures "the same intention" as a weapon or perhaps as a piece of armor. Here this metaphor means that believers should be determined in their mind to suffer as Jesus did. AT: "prepare yourselves with the same thoughts that Christ had" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: arm yourselves with the same intention

contextId.information: will soon happen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: is coming

contextId.information: In the same way that fire refines gold, trials test and refine a person's faith. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the testing in the fire that has happened to you

contextId.information: This phrase refers to believers, whom Peter speaks of as God's family. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: household of God

contextId.information: Elders are to lead by example and not act toward the people as a harsh master would toward his servants. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not act as a master over the people ... Instead, be an example

contextId.information: Peter speaks of Jesus as if he is a shepherd who has authority over all other shepherds. This can be stated in active form. AT: "When Jesus, the Chief Shepherd, appears" or "When God reveals Jesus, the Chief Shepherd" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Then when the Chief Shepherd is revealed

contextId.information: Peter speaks of having the moral quality of humility as putting on a piece of clothing. AT: "act humbly toward each other" (UDB) or "act with humility" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: clothe yourselves with humility

contextId.information: Peter speaks of anxiety as if it were a heavy burden that a person places on God, rather than carrying it himself. AT: "Trust him with everything that worries you" or "Let him take care of all the things that trouble you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Cast all your anxiety on him

contextId.information: Peter speaks of fellow believers as members of the same community. AT: "your fellow believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your community

contextId.information: Peter speaks of Mark as if he is his spiritual son. AT: "my spiritual son" or "who is like a son to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my son
